4.95.text: about the wonderful gardens here at Blakesley Hall.

8.49.text: Since 2002 we've been developing these gardens

12.22.text: as an extension of the interpretation of the Tudor hall.

16.49.text: We have a kitchen garden where I am now.

22.35.text: of useful plants for use in the hall.

26.61.text: which was a good cure for stomach complaints

83.56.text: Welcome to Blakesley Hall, please follow me inside.

88.87.text: It is often thought that the Tudors

90.75.text: were a very smelly bunch of people.

92.57.text: They certainly did not care for washing

94.20.text: and they certainly weren't bothered by bad smells.

96.44.text: However this is far from the truth.

98.58.text: They were very concerned with how they smelt personally

101.12.text: and also how their homes smelt.

103.49.text: And a lot of time and effort was spent in masking these smells.

107.78.text: Now for most people during the Tudor period

110.16.text: a daily bath would not have been possible.

112.50.text: It would have been very inconvenient

117.33.text: is that they would have actually had a daily wash

119.88.text: using water in a bowel just like this.

122.74.text: In household manuals of the day

124.32.text: they are giving an abundance of recipes

128.20.text: Now washing waters were simply water

130.30.text: put into a bowl with herbs such as lavender added to it.

134.73.text: that the herbs would make the water very fragrant

136.64.text: and make the person smell very nice.

141.58.text: for the less well off in society

144.89.text: Soap that was made of animal fat or tallow.

151.32.text: So the water with the herbs in

155.47.text: It also became very popular for people to wear perfume.

159.17.text: Originally this was thought to again

160.89.text: mask the odour coming from a person.

164.61.text: is that it was used a status symbol.

166.99.text: And this is because the spices and herbs used to make

170.09.text: perfume had to be imported from foreign countries.

173.95.text: Now to import something cost a lot money

176.31.text: so in order to do that you have to be very wealthy indeed.

179.83.text: So if you could afford to import theses spices

183.09.text: people knew you were very rich.

185.62.text: However what did become very popular

191.28.text: was the idea of wearing a tussy mussy.

194.02.text: Now a tussy mussy is a small sweet smelling bouquet

198.29.text: would have worn upon there clothing.

201.34.text: And it was very easy to make

202.63.text: and also a lot cheaper than perfume.

204.80.text: You at home can also make one

206.49.text: all you need is one sweet smelling flower

210.44.text: surround it with springs of lavender

215.09.text: And they would have tied a ribbon

216.67.text: around the bottom of it, like so.

218.93.text: And then attach this to there clothing

221.20.text: and this would have ensured that they constantly had

223.59.text: a nice fragrant smell coming from this tussy mussy.

227.75.text: Now we know that the Tudors spent a lot of time

230.12.text: trying to make their person smell as lovely as possible.

232.95.text: But they also spent a lot of time

234.88.text: trying to make their home equally as fragrant.

238.24.text: Here in the great hall the floor is not original.

241.45.text: The floor would have been about a foot lower

243.46.text: when the house was first built.

245.02.text: And it would have been made of ox blood,

248.72.text: So as you can imagine, really quite wiffy.

252.01.text: Now the servants would have tried to cover this smell up

255.30.text: particularly if the family had guests.

257.61.text: And what they would have done

259.05.text: is they would have laid some rushes along the floor

261.86.text: on top of this they would have laid herbs like lavender.

264.84.text: Now the idea was when these herbs were walked on

268.90.text: they would have released a very sweet smelling

270.62.text: fragrance thus masking the smell of the floor.

274.41.text: Another useful thing they did was create lavender bags.

278.09.text: Now they would have made these

279.40.text: using a small piece of fabric, like so

281.63.text: they would have put the lavender inside

283.74.text: tied them up, attached a ribbon

286.11.text: then hung them in the rooms of the house.

288.91.text: Now we know this worked because there is

294.16.text: 'Hung up in houses doth very well a temper

296.76.text: to cool and make fresh the place

299.48.text: to the comforts and pleasure of those there in.'

302.26.text: So obviously lavender bags did work.

307.93.text: as an excellent deterrent for pests.

309.97.text: For some reason they thought that pests

313.73.text: So because of this lavender sprigs

315.79.text: were put in the mattress to deter vermin.

317.90.text: And also lavender sprigs were put into clothes chests.

325.10.text: were deterred from eating the clothes

328.15.text: particularly if the family were wealthy

330.00.text: and therefore had fine silks and velvets.

334.35.text: that when they did want to use them

336.23.text: they already smelt very sweetly of lavender

338.28.text: rather than a musty clothes storage smell.

343.17.text: I really hope this video has shown you

345.09.text: some of the ways in which lavender

346.69.text: was used inside the Tudor home.
